document.docAuthor: MUGRABI, DANIELE F. & AZEVEDO, CELSO O.
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of Thai Dissomphalus Ashmead, 1893 (Hymenoptera, Bethylidae), with description of twenty four new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of Thai Dissomphalus Ashmead, 1893 (Hymenoptera, Bethylidae), with description of twenty four new species

bibRefCitation.author: Terayama
bibRefCitation.refString: Terayama, M. (2001) Descriptions of seven new species of the genus Dissomphalus Ashmead (Hymenoptera, Bethylidae) from the Oriental Region. Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology, 7 (1), 81 - 90.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Dissomphalus thaianus Terayama 2001: 86
( ♂ , description, fig. 16-19); 2003: 13 (cladistic analysis).

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. MALE. Mandible with three apical teeth. Clypeus with trapezoidal median lobe, median carina straight and low in profile. Frons coriaceous, frontal impression short, punctures shallow, dense and large. Vertex broad, slightly convex. Tergal process with pair of circular, very shallow submedian depression, tubercle short, wide, tuft of dense, short setae, tubercle and tuft directed upward ( Figs 19–21 ). Genitalia large with dorsal body wider medially; aedeagal ventral ramus wide, wider medially, not reach base of apical lobe of dorsal body; aedeagal apodeme extending much far beyond genital ring, apical region curved mesad.

materialsCitation.collectorName: Forest, M. & E. Fuller & Doi Phahompok NP & Komwuan Srisom & Prasit Wongchai & Huai Nam Dang NP & Thawatchai Boonthum & Anuchart Chaimuengchun

Remarks.
Dissomphalus thaianus
was known as the most abundant species in Thailand (see Terayama 2001 ). This species represents about 10% of the material collected for the present study, which corroborates the data on its large abundance.
D. barbus
sp. nov.
and
D. magnetus
sp. nov.
are similar to
D. thaianus
because of the following characteristics: basiparamere and paramere narrow in dorsal view, aedeagal dorsal body wide and ventral ramus wider medially. However, dorsal body of
D. thaianus
is wider medially, and the apex of the inner lobes is little exposed; the length of the ventral ramus does not reach the base of the apical lobe of dorsal body, which is wider medially; and the aedeagal apodeme extends much far beyond the genital ring, and has its apical region curved mesad.

Distribution. Thailand ( Chiang Mai , Mae Hong Son , Sakon Nakhon , Phitsanulok , Loei , Phetchabun , Kamphaeng Phet , Chaiyaphum , Ubon Ratchathani , Suphanburi , Kanchanaburi , Nakhon Ratchasima , Nakhon Nayok , Bangkok , Petchaburi, Chanthaburi , Prachuap Khiri Khan and Surat Thani ); India ( Karnataka and Tamil Nadu ).
